title: Direct Drive Bowden Extruder for 20 mm extrusion

description.text:
Direct Drive Bowden Extruder that latches on (bolt free) to 20mm extrusion. Can also be fixed in place with a single bolt. Features:
-simple, open, & compact
-easy to clean and adjust
-designed to be drilled out for 1.75 or 3mm filament
-designed to be drilled out for a 5mm or 1/8 coupling
-will work with the shown Arcol hobbed pulley or a mk7
-pulley is positioned close to motor base to reduce cantilevered load on motor shaft
Inspired by every other open source extruder out there.
Note: I am using an 86oz*in motor with a DRV8825 stepper driver on 1.75mm filament. You may want to use a geared stepper driver for 3mm filament. They can be found on ebay. Just make sure they can still mount on the normal Nema 17 bolt pattern.

Note: I've included a mirror image of the extruder. Delete what you don't want. You will also need to split the object to print the arm to the side of the base or it will print on top. Easy in slic3r.
Note2: added Extruder 1.4NPT to accommodate larger pneumatic fittings.
Requires:
1x Nema 17 Stepper with high torque capability
1x hobbed pulley w set screw (5mm ID)
1x pneumatic coupling
1x 625 bearing
3x M3-8mm bolt
1x M3-12 to 16mm bolt
1x M5-12mm bolt w nut
1x M5-30+mm bolt w nut & washer
1x spring to fit over M5 bolt
I used a knurled nut for the spring tensioner but a normal or winged nut could be used. Might want to print off something similar to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:102153

comments.text: Very nice work. Looks like a great design. I am running a Bowden now that I got from Thingiverse that uses a geared motor. The motor was running very hot. I added a fan and heatsink and it solved the problem. Have you had any heat issues with your design and the ungeared motor?
comments.author: ralphferro

comments.text: Got up to 360% default speeds (30/60) and didn't overheat or skip.  That said the object was a small 25mm cube so it was probably restricted by acceleration limits which I've left at the default Marlin/slic3r settings.  Still no fan, but tuning the stepper driver to this point was trial and error.
comments.author: ralphferro

comments.text: What gear ratio are you using?  If you are geared down you shouldn't be heating up much unless you are using 3mm filament.  I am using 1.75mm which needs less driving pressure (force/area).  I have added a 40x40mm heat sink to mine mainly because I had it.  No fan yet, but I haven't gone beyond default slicer speeds (30/60).  No missed steps.  Motor is warm to touch, if it becomes hot it will be very easy to add a fan the hooks onto the extrusion like the whole assembly does.
comments.author: ralphferro

comments.text: The drill size for tapping 1/4" NPT is 7/16" (11.1125mm) in diameter.  There is 5.5R mm in material so there is not enough.  A 6mm to 1/8"PT fitting would work though.  Did you already buy that fitting?  If so, I can look at tweaking the file a bit to make yours work.
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text: Would a 1/4 x 6mm pneumatic fitting would work? I want to use 3mm filament...
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: The drill size for tapping 1/4" NPT is 7/16" (11.1125mm) in diameter.  There is 5.5R mm in material so there is not enough.  A 6mm to 1/8"PT fitting would work though.  Did you already buy that fitting?  If so, I can look at tweaking the file a bit to make yours work.  Just let me know.
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: Thanks for the answer, I already bought 6 to 1/4! I didnt knew can you help me?
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text: New file added.  Extruder 1.4 should accommodate your larger fittings.
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: I dont know how to split the idler to print on the side of the base...=$
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text: I am guessing you figured it out?  If you are using slic3r, there is an option at the top to split a stl file containing multiple objects.  Just select the imported object (turns red), then hit the split button.  You may then need to drag the split objects away from each other.
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: I load the file into slic3r in Repetier Host V .95, in the objects tab there I select Split Object and it only separates into two objects the original and the mirror, so I delete the mirror, but I cant move away the idler from the object...
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text: "spreadout" file added.  Let me know if that works.  If not I will add 4 separate files.
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: I print off of an SD card but used pronterface before that.  I never liked it's auto slic3r capabilities so I'd run slic3r independently the load the G-code.  I can split the files and upload them independently tonight.
comments.author: inv4der

comments.text: Thanks I'm printing it right now!

title: Filament spool wall-mount truss bracket. Hidden Screws!

description.text:
Brackets to wall-mount a dowel (19mm) to hold multiple spools of filament. I've currently got over 5kg of material up. I'll let you know if it falls on my printer! Hidden screws! How exciting.  
Edit: I took off a few kg. Now I have ~3.5 on there. Also, make sure to print this on it's side. Not sure about you by if I tried to bridge those trusses, it would be a disaster. Plus, the surface shown facing the buildplate in the CAD image is not flat.

I think if a model is featured it should be printable.
I love seeing the cool things that are featured.
However, I'm frequently disappointed when I can't actually print them.
I've modified this thing so you might actually be able to print it.

Print all three parts glue together and enjoy.
Warning!  I'm in the process of printing this unprintable thing so you may expect the files to change.
I printed it but the legs are way too brittle to be of any use and the head won't fit into the body unless you sand off the little lip at the bottom of it.

author: luismanson

description.text: Fernbank L.I.N.K.S. team 4468 has designed a quick and easy way to mount electronics on dual cim gearboxes. With hex holes so you can sync #8 nuts into the plastic for easily removal and reattachment of components. One of the models holds the digital side car another holds the bridge and power converter and the last holds 2 victors for the drive motors.

After 3D printing the parts put a #8 bolt through one of the holes with the head on the top side then put a #8 nut on it and tighten it all the way. It will be a tight fit but go up into the hex hole and eventually you wont be able to tighten any more. At this point unscrew the #8 bolt. The nut should stay lodged in the plastic. Repeat for every hole when you are done you can easily attach components. The holes on the sides are for zip-tying the mount onto the motors.

comments.text: We did not have any trouble with this last year, but we also had our CIMs on a low gearing for heavy defense. This was a concern of ours but we never had any problems with it.
comments.author: Amo10

comments.text: Will this not melt the plastic because the CIMs will create too much heat?

author: v1018

title: Sony NEX SEL18200 Tripod ring mount

description.text:
Sony NEX SEL18200 18-200mm lens tripod mount. This mounts to your SEL18200 lens to eliminate the issue some people are having with this heavy lens causing cracking around the NEX series camera tripod mount. You simple mount your quick release plate to this mount and the camera will be a lot more stable and will remove risk of damage to your camera mount. You will require a M3x20 bolt and nut for the top clamp, and a 1/4 20 nut for the bottom mount. Due to different printer tolerances, some nuts may be hard to push into place, but will fit, maybe with a little filing or sanding.
There are 3 files, the one marked rev 1 is an updated version which has been tidied up a little and prints much nicer. (grey one in picture is original, black one is revised design)
The one marked Rev 2 is updated, I found that with the fixing on top it gets in the way of a speedlite, fixing has been moved to the side and a relief added to the top.
Revision 3 coming soon, just to tidy a couple of things up.
Note: This is for the original SEL18200, not the SEL18200LE and not the power zoom version. If you are looking for the SEL18200LE, please see my other items.
Mount shown in my photos are of a slightly older version, will update pictures when i get a chance.

Made four m4/m16 type flash hiders with 14mm negative threads. The first two flash hiders are the common bird cage design, the third is closed with no holes in the sides, and the fourth is the three prong type. Print with standard 0.2, no supports are needed. Updated files with better threading so they will be easier to thread on to the end of the barrel.  
Update: Spent the week working on the threads. Had some complaints about the tight threads so I am releasing new versions that have looser threads.

comments.text:
Man you saved me! I've lost countless time waiting for the Vietnam hider become available on the store i was following!
Finally i can complete my Dawn of the Dead swat cosplay!
There are two version of the file, what's the left screw one?
comments.author: IllGib

comments.text: When I printed out the three prong the diameter of the threaded hole was a little too small to fit on my friends m4, I had to modify it a little. Just to let you know.
comments.author: UncleBourbon

comments.text: Did you have any luck getting it to fit better? I printed one at 0.1mm layer height and it was still a little too snug.
comments.author: UncleBourbon

comments.text: I have to file down the inside of the flash hide to get it to fit right. My best bet will just be widening the radius in the model in like blender or something. because if I were to file out the inside I would also have to tap it..
